race.name: WHISKEY OFF-ROAD
race.tagline: The OG Southwest MTB festival. Skull Valley will break you. Whiskey Row will rebuild you.

vitals.registration: Tiered pricing, register early for best rate. Sells out.
vitals.aid_stations: Multiple well-stocked aid stations throughout course

climate.primary: High desert springâ€”mild average, but wildly unpredictable
climate.description: April in Prescott averages 66-67F highs and 34F lows with minimal precipitation. But race weekend is notorious for weather roulette. Past years have seen everything from 80F+ with 102F exposed climb readings to freezing rain, hail, and snow at elevation. The forum consensus: 'come prepared to ride in all kinds of weather.'
challenges: 102F possible on exposed Skull Valley climb

terrain.primary: Classic Southwest MTB with singletrack, fire roads, and technical descents
terrain.surface: Mixed: singletrack, doubletrack, gravel roads, some pavement
features: Trail 48 rocky singletrack with water bars
Trail 367 boulder drop section near finish

logistics.explanation: Andrea Wilson notes the Pro category gets "privileged to our own start" avoiding "the misery of traffic jams" from mass amateur starts. Phoenix Sky Harbor is a major hub but requires a 2-hour drive to Prescott. The event is walkable once you arriveâ€”park downtown and access all weekend activities on foot.

length.explanation: The 50 Proof course runs 46.2 miles with multiple distance options from 15-50 miles. Andrea Wilson finished in 4 hours, 10 minutes despite mechanical issues. Wilson observed early pacing strategy: "I knew some of the women ahead of me were going harder than what they should, so I stuck with my effort." Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course features "technical singletrack" with water bars on Trail 48's rocky sections. Wilson noted descending challenges: "nearly made contact with a prickly pear cactus bush the size of a smartcar." The hard left turn onto singletrack creates a critical pinch point where "you want to be in the top 10 or 15 entering the single track, or you'll play catch-up all day." More technical than most â€” comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: Over 6,000 feet of climbing includes the notorious Skull Valley climb where Wilson experienced severe cramping. The course starts with a "long climb out of town" before the "long dirt road climb out of Skull Valley." Riders face sustained elevation from Prescott's 5,400ft start to 7,011ft maximum elevation. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: 2024 race weekend saw dramatic weather swingsâ€”Friday started "beautiful" and "sunny" but "temperature dropped about 20 degrees to somewhere in the 30s, and the rain started." The storm brought hail and forced Fat Tire Crit cancellation. April conditions range from perfect to brutal within hours. Milder conditions than Crusher in the Tushar.

altitude.explanation: Racing at 5,300-7,000ft affects performance noticeably. Wilson noted: "The altitude had a little bit to do with it. It was day #3 at ~5300ft, so it would explain why I'd felt like a rockstar on Friday but maybe a little blunted on Sunday." Meaningful enough to cause late-race energy depletion. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Starting from Prescott's historic Whiskey Row creates iconic atmosphere. Wilson described the initial climb as "eerily quiet with the exception of the pockets of crowds that had gathered to cheer us along." The high desert terrain offers "sick descents" through Prescott National Forest's granite formations and pine forests.

prestige.explanation: Hannah Otto calls Whiskey "a premiere event on the off-road calendar" that she's "always known of" and "held in high regard." The race attracts elite talentâ€”Toby Hassett "decided to potentially blow up the rest of his race to go head-to-head with two of the fastest mountain bikers in the world" for a $1,000 prime, beating Keegan Swenson and Cole Paton.

race_quality.explanation: Epic Rides delivers professional execution with separate Pro starts avoiding amateur race chaos. The 94% finish rate reflects well-marked courses and proper aid station placement. When weather forced Friday crit cancellation, half the women's field "braved the sideways rain and hail, and did a parade lap to thank the spectators"â€”showing both rider dedication and event culture.

experience.explanation: Three-day festival atmosphere creates lasting memories beyond just racing. The event immerses participants "in an atmosphere buzzing with mountain bike culture, surrounded by fellow biking aficionados." Post-race scenes show "hundreds of people, tired but happy, kicking it with new and old friends in the center of a small American town with bikes strewn around far and wide."

community.explanation: Race director Todd Sadow emphasizes community focus: "We're not Life Time, we're not Ironman, but we put on events that draw a similar audience in size. However we see our events differently and more rooted in community." The downtown festival with beer gardens, live music, and historic Whiskey Row creates "an atmosphere buzzing with mountain bike culture."

field_depth.explanation: Pro field includes established talent like Keegan Swenson and Cole Paton competing for $1,000 primes, with Andrew L'Esperance noting that with proper preparation "the win would've been 100% on the table." Wilson finished 27th of 44 in Pro women's category, acknowledging "the all-star nature of the field" while hoping for top-half placement. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three.

value.explanation: 'Expensive' appears consistently in forum reviews. High production value justifies the costâ€”you're getting a weekend festival, not just a race. Includes shirt, finisher pint, expo access, concert. But budget-conscious riders notice the premium pricing. Entry tier pricing rewards early registration. As Fat Tire Crit atmosphere puts it: "The controlled chaos of the Fat Tire Crit gets me stoked to return to Prescott every year. And I know many pro racers feel the same way..."

expenses.explanation: Phoenix flights are affordable (major hub). But add 2-hour drive, lodging in tourist-friendly Prescott, and premium registration fees. Budget $500-1,000 total for travel/lodging/entry. Not extreme, but not budget-friendly either. Camping options can reduce costs significantly. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

biased_opinion.summary: The Whiskey Off-Road is the Southwest's premier mountain bike festivalâ€”a 20-year institution that combines genuine physical challenge with exceptional event production. Skull Valley will humble you. The technical sections demand MTB skills. But the weekend packageâ€”historic Whiskey Row, live music, expo, communityâ€”elevates it beyond just a race. It's what happens when an event organizer spends two decades perfecting their craft.
strengths: 20+ years of refinement by Epic Ridesâ€”logistics are dialed
Festival atmosphere with expo, crit, and free Greensky Bluegrass concert
Genuine MTB challenge with technical sections and massive climbing
Historic Prescott setting adds character and post-race entertainment
weaknesses: Premium pricingâ€”'expensive' appears consistently in reviews
2-hour drive from Phoenix airport, lodging books fast
Weather rouletteâ€”could be 102F or snowing on race day
This is MTB, not gravelâ€”technical sections may frustrate road crossover riders
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want to experience what a mature, well-produced MTB festival looks like, Whiskey delivers. Just come prepared for Skull Valley to test your limits.

black_pill.title: SKULL VALLEY DOESN'T CARE ABOUT YOUR TRAINING PLAN
black_pill.reality: The Skull Valley climb is 12 miles of exposed fire road with 2,500-2,700ft of elevation gain. It comes at the halfway point when you're already depleted. Even Payson McElveen admits he cramps 75% of Whiskey races. Past riders have documented heat exhaustion, knife-like cramps that drop them trailside, and complete mental breakdown. The forum testimonials read like war stories: 'I started screaming from knife-like cramps seizing both legs about 10 miles from the finish.'
consequences: Cramping is endemicâ€”even elite pros succumb to it regularly
Heat exhaustion documented between aid stations in hot years
5-6% DNF rate means dozens abandon each year (50% off next year offered)
Bottleneck at singletrack transitionâ€”start position determines your race
No refunds on registration regardless of circumstances
black_pill.expectation_reset: Respect Skull Valley. Don't go out too hard. Hydrate aggressively for days before the race. Bring more electrolytes than you think you need. Accept that cramping might happen anyway. The start bottleneck means passing is nearly impossible on singletrackâ€”seed yourself appropriately or accept your pack. And check the weather obsessively, but accept that April in Arizona can throw anything at you.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Southwest's 20-year MTB institution where Skull Valley tests your suffering and Whiskey Row rewards your survival.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a world-class MTB festival experience with genuine physical challenge. Yes if you appreciate 20 years of event refinement. No if you're a gravel purist uncomfortable on technical terrain. No if you need budget-friendly entry.
final_verdict.alternatives: Grand Junction Off-Road (Epic Rides sister event); Sea Otter Classic (bigger festival, coastal); Crusher in the Tushar (more altitude suffering, less festival)

logistics.lodging_strategy: Book earlyâ€”Prescott fills up. Partner hotels: SpringHill Suites (4 blocks, bike wash), Hassayampa Inn (on square, historic), Best Western Prescottonian. Alternatives: Airbnb/VRBO, White Spar Campground (3mi from downtown), Prescott National Forest dispersed camping.
logistics.food: Concentrated around downtown square and Whiskey Row. Full options in tourist-friendly Prescott.
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday. Mandatory Pre-Ride Meeting Friday 7:00 PM on Main Stage.
logistics.parking: Designated areasâ€”respect local businesses. Event designed for walkability once parked.
logistics.camping:
Camping area, slightly further out

### Event Weekend Flow

Epic Rides designed the weekend so participants can:
- Arrive Friday

history.origin_story: Todd Sadow founded Epic Rides in 1999 with the 24 Hours in the Old Pueblo. The Whiskey Off-Road launched around 2004-2005 and took five years to develop the multi-distance model that would become the template for Epic Rides' national expansion. 'We spent five years creating what is known as the Whiskey Off-Road today,' Sadow says. The key innovation was realizing 'only so many could do longer races' and adding 30-mile and 50-mile options.
notable_moments: 2013: Grand Junction Off-Road launches, replicating Whiskey model
Epic Rides expands to Nevada (Carson City) and Arkansas (Oz Trails)
Event now draws ~2,000 riders annually with 8,500+ across Epic Rides portfolio
history.reputation: The original Epic Rides modelâ€”proof that 20 years of iteration creates exceptional events.

course_description.character: A greatest-hits tour of Prescott National Forest combining technical singletrack, flowing trails, exposed fire road grinding, and tactical racing. You start on historic Whiskey Row, climb through granite formations, suffer through Skull Valley, flow through Spence Basin, and navigate technical descents when your legs are cooked. Every type of MTB terrain represented.

suffering_zones.label: Copper Basin Climb
suffering_zones.desc: 3.8-mile opening climb sets the tone. Get in your pack hereâ€”singletrack bottleneck coming.

suffering_zones.label: Trail 48
suffering_zones.desc: Classic rocky singletrack with multiple water bars. Technical climbing where passing is nearly impossible.

suffering_zones.label: Skull Valley
suffering_zones.desc: The signature suffer-fest. 12 miles of exposed fire road with 2,500-2,700ft gain. Hot, relentless, cramping epidemic. This is where races are lost and legends are made.

suffering_zones.label: Cramp Hill
suffering_zones.desc: Just when you think you're recovering from Skull Valley. Another climb when your legs are toast.

suffering_zones.label: Trail 367 Boulder Drop
suffering_zones.desc: Technical descent with boulder sections. Hits when you're most depleted and least focused.

course_description.signature_challenge: Skull Valleyâ€”a 12-mile exposed fire road climb at the halfway mark. 2,500-2,700ft of gain when you're already depleted. Documented 102F readings in hot years. Where cramping becomes universal and mental fortitude separates finishers from DNFs.

special_features.duo_team: 50-Proof Duo Team Category: Team relay format modeled after South Africa's Cape Epic
special_features.single_speed: Dedicated single speed categoriesâ€”course is 'very rigid SS friendly' per forum consensus
special_features.pro_crit: Saturday Pro Criterium in downtown Prescott
special_features.music: Free Greensky Bluegrass concert Saturday evening
special_features.expo: Three-day Bike & Gear Expo access included with registration
special_features.beneficiaries: Event supports Yavapai County Food Bank and Prevent Child Abuse Arizona

citations.label: cxhairs.substack.com: Big Money Prime Shakes Up Whiskey

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Bite
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

primary.name: WTB Resolute
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: 2025 Whiskey 50 Mile Off-Road - Prescott, Arizona
videos.description:
Alright folks, buckle up for a wild ride! ðŸ¤  I took on the legendary Whiskey 50 Off-Road Race again, and let me tell you, it was a doozy! From epic climbs to thrilling descents (and maybe a few grunts along the way!), this video is your front-row seat to all the action.

I shot and narrated this entire thing while riding, so you're getting the raw, real experience straight from the bike. You'll see the highs, the lows, and everything in between that makes this race a truly unforgettable adventure.

If you love mountain biking, crazy challenges, or just want to see what it's like to tackle 50 miles off-road, then this video is for you!

Let me know in the comments if you've ever ridden the Whiskey 50 or what your favorite off-road race is!

videos.title: Whiskey Off-Road - 15, 30 or 50 miles of trailside bliss and good vibes on Whiskey Row
videos.description: Choose from three different distance options of 15, 30 or 50 miles; each consisting of a carefully curated set of trails in Prescott, AZ. Starting on Prescottâ€™s historic (and lively) Whiskey Row and climbing into the beautiful Prescott National Forest. During your visit to Prescott, enjoy three fun-filled days of event festivities and being submerged in the mountain bike industry.

videos.title: Whiskey Off Road 15-Proof - FULL COURSE RIDE - 2025  - 2026 | Prescott, Arizona MTB Race Course
videos.description:
Iâ€™ve been asked about the Whiskey Off Road 15-proof Friday fun ride over the years. The Whiskey Off Road is 3-day (Friday-Sunday) mountain bike event and race held each spring here in Prescott, Arizona. There are 15-, 25-, and 50-mile (proof) options. The 15-proof (closer to 20 miles) fun ride is held on Friday. I have never raced the 15-proof, although I have raced the 50-proof and 30-proof a handful of times. For those that have asked; here you go. Have a safe and fun race. Good luck! And . .
Have a great ride. -- goMTB prescottAZ.

*NOTE: I knew I was going to have to do one camera battery swap for this ride. I deliberately chose to do this early at the Aspen Creek aid location prior to the start of the singletrack. The result is uninterrupted footage of all the singletrack to the end. 

*TIP: There are a few places that may hang up a rider if theyâ€™ve never ridden this course before:
Trail 393  -    46:50
Trail 327  -    50:48
Trail 321  - 1:01:42

*HISTORY NOTE: Trail(s) 327 and 393 were part of the earliest versions of the Whiskey Off Road course going back to 2004. Racers came the opposite direction on these up to the Aspen Creek aid station.

Season Rode/Recorded: SPRING

videos.title: Whiskey Off-Road Bike Race Prescott Arizona 2024
videos.description:
Epic Rides Whiskey Off-Road Bike Race is one of Prescott, Arizonaâ€™s signature events. Mountain biking enthusiasts, their families and fans flock to Prescottâ€™s famous Whiskey Row in the heart of downtown. The Whiskey Off-Road is considered to be one of the best MTB events in the entire southwestern United States. Great weather and hundreds of miles of hiking and biking trails draw thousands to Prescott every year, and are two more reasons people want to move here!

EPIC RIDES 2025 WHISKEY OFF-ROAD NOTIFICATION SIGN-UP:
https://epicrides.com/events/whiskey-off-road/2025-whiskey-off-road-pre-registration/

videos.title: Conquering The Epic Rides Whiskey 50 Backcountry Race!
videos.description:
Join me for an adrenaline-packed adventure as we take on the Epic Rides Whiskey 50 backcountry race in Prescott, Arizona. In this 50-mile race with just shy of 7,000 feet of climbing, I'll face challenging terrain, high altitudes, and unexpected obstacles that will push me to my limits. From the historic Whiskey Row to the rugged Skull Valley, we'll journey through some of the most beautiful scenery Arizona has to offer. 

#mtb #whiskey50 #mtbraddad

videos.curation_reason: High-quality first-person race recap with detailed course conditions and altitude challenges.

quotes.text: Here's the turnaround down at Skull Valley and this is really where I think the race starts because this climb back up here - you're climbing for quite a long way back up past where we made the junction right up to the top of the hill before you get any reprieve. So in reality, it's about an hour long climb for me.

The altitude of the race posed a significant challenge - the starting point was at approximately 5,300 feet with the highest point reaching 7,000 feet. During the initial two hours I struggled with a high heart rate that drained most of my energy.

key_challenges.name: Skull Valley climb
key_challenges.description: About an hour-long climb after the turnaround at Skull Valley. Described as brutal climbing at elevation. The climb goes back up past the junction to the top of the hill before any reprieve.

key_challenges.name: Split at Moby and 48
key_challenges.description: Early in the race, riders must choose between Moby and 48 routes. Described as the first thing to mess with your head. The routes rejoin later.

key_challenges.name: Cramp Hill
key_challenges.description: A climbing section that riders mention by name, though one rider noted not remembering it clearly.

terrain_notes.text: Very different terrain from buff riding to very technical, very loose, very steep, very rocky. Trails are described as very challenging.
Very narrow trail, very rocky sections that don't get huge amounts of traffic. Some areas require careful line selection due to loose conditions.
Hidden rocks are a concern on the technical sections. The terrain is described as worse than other comparable races in terms of difficulty.

race_day_tips.text: Limited opportunities to consume energy gels or reach water bottles while on the move. The course design offers limited spots where riders can safely reach down and grab bottles during early stages.
Be careful of traffic going both directions on the downhill out to Skull Valley. Fast riders are coming back up the hill.
The race really starts at the Skull Valley turnaround because of the long climb back up. Prepare for about an hour of climbing and heavy breathing.

additional_quotes.text: This 50 mile race has just shy of 7000 feet of climbing. We're starting in the historic Whiskey Row here in Prescott Arizona and the energy here is off the charts.

The altitude posed a significant challenge. The starting point was at approximately 5300 feet with the highest point reaching 7000 feet. During the initial two hours I struggled with a high heart rate that drained most my energy.

It's grown immensely, it's one of our favorite events. It's just been a great community, just a lot of good down-to-earth people. You can just feel the vibe, everybody's just so cool and laid back and happy.

rider_intel.search_text: The Whiskey Off-Road 50-mile race in Prescott, Arizona features just shy of 7000 feet of climbing, starting at 5300 feet elevation and reaching 7000 feet at the highest point. The course begins on historic Whiskey Row and includes challenging terrain ranging from buff riding to very technical, loose, steep, and rocky sections. Key challenges include the brutal Skull Valley climb, described as about an hour of sustained climbing after the turnaround point. Early in the race, riders face a route choice between Moby and 48 sections. The course offers limited opportunities for nutrition due to technical terrain that makes reaching bottles difficult. Riders note hidden rocks, narrow rocky trails, and the need for careful line selection on downhills with two-way traffic. The elevation significantly impacts performance, particularly in the first two hours. The race finishes with new single track sections and is known for its welcoming community atmosphere in the cowboy town of Prescott.
